thread.title: A heavy load for the energy regulator
thread.title_full: A heavy load for the energy regulator | Business Spectator

author: Keith Orchison
title: A heavy load for the energy regulator
text:
Even in the age of hyperbole, $12.8 billion is not a small sum, the more so when it represents money consumers are not going to spend.
The money is the difference between what the Australian Energy Regulator has been asked to sanction as electricity network revenue between mid-2015 and mid-2020 for 10 grid businesses and what the watchdog is willing to let them recoup from users of their delivery lines.
The aggregate bids totalled $45.7bn and the amount the AER proposes to allow is $32.9bn.
This arithmetic represents only seven final determinations for networks by the regulator and three preliminary decisions.
The former are focused on New South Wales and the ACT and are now the subject of vigorous exchanges between a regiment of lawyers in the Australian Competition Tribunal in Sydney; the latter are the AER’s first go at determinations for the two Queensland distributors and the one in South Australia.
Decisions for Victoria are still to come.
While this represents some pretty heavy lifting for the regulator, now marking its tenth birthday, it is by no means all that the AER faces.
In an annual review, just published, that tries to sketch the whole regulatory picture, new chair Paula Conboy has invited her predecessors to provide their reflections too -- and they make interesting reading.
Steve Edwell (chair from 2005 to 2010) suggests that the AER is facing a “tsunami” of issues, even more challenging than those of the past decade.
It’s a wave driven by technology and consumers, he says, the latter across the country responding to higher energy prices by reducing consumption and, when they are householders (about a quarter of the users), “aggressively” reaching for rooftop solar panels.
Edwell queries whether the network regulatory framework, which was given a thorough shaking only two years ago, is able to cope with an environment of falling renewable energy costs, innovation in energy storage, embedded generation developments and “greater consumer empowerment” through the roll-out of smart meters?
“Do we need another round of regulatory change?” Edwell asks -- and, if we do, can the AER and the networks sector make it happen or will we need further policymaker intervention?
For his part, Edwell feels that perhaps the best response will be widening contestability along the electricity supply chain and recourse to less rather than more regulation of network assets. “The long-term interests of consumers may be best met by letting the market rip,” he says.
Conboy’s immediate predecessor, Andrew Reeves (chair from 2010 to 2014, a period when a new regulatory approach initiated by governments saw more than $40bn in capex outlayed by the power networks and charges effectively double, resulting in unprecedented political turmoil over electricity policy), agrees that the most significant recent change is the shift in focus to consumers.
The east coast energy market rule-maker, the Australian Energy Market Commission, in its review -- also just published -- has opted to headline the report, It’s all about consumers .
Reeves says that, after being sidelined for much of the history of economic regulation in Australia, consumers are now central to decisions -- and the next 10 years will see them dominating centre stage even more.
He underlines the challenge posed for the AER and governments by the impending restructuring of network tariffs, which, he says, will shift the burden of charges for use of power systems.
An important issue, he adds, is that there must be consistency in the principles and objectives of regulation, especially in pursuing efficient investment. (Networks, of course, are being continuously accused in public debate of being inefficient investors, a criticism they vigorously contest, not least in the current tribunal hearing examining the AER’s recent decisions and its new benchmarking approach.)
Another contributor to the regulator’s annual review is former board member Ed Willett, who makes two interesting observations.
The east coast electricity market, he declares, is “by a clear margin” the best in the world -- but it has “clear vulnerabilities.”
Network prices are too high. The wholesale contract market is too thin. The power spot market’s continuing viability -- rather than performing as “a mere dispatch engine” -- is at risk. Demand-side participation “remains formative.”
For all this, Willett reminds critics of the regulatory system, to remember where we started: at the beginning of the century national competition policy energy reforms “had run out of puff” and federal, state and territory energy policy processes “were moribund”.
There have been “hiccups” along the way, he acknowledges, but “the big picture has been smooth implementation of fundamental changes in a difficult political environment”.
This is probably a red rag for the many agitated consumer bodies (not to mention agitated network managers) now crowding the debate but perhaps they all should remember that Victorian adage: “keep a tight hold of nurse for fear of getting something worse.”
